snippet: Money-transfer companies like Western Union largely escaped the regulatory crackdown in the wake of the financial crisis, but soon they will be subject to new federal rules.
abstract: Money-transfer companies like Western Union have largely escaped the regulatory crackdown in the wake of the financial crisis, causing mounting frustration particularly among immigrants who pay high fees to send money home; companies will soon have to disclose more to customers about transfer fees and currency exchange rates, but consumer advocates say the regulations should extend to service pricing.
lead_paragraph: Money-transfer companies like Western Union largely escaped the regulatory crackdown in the wake of the financial crisis, but soon they will be subject to new federal rules.

headline.seo: New Rules for Money Transfers, but Few Limits
headline.main: New Rules for Money Transfers, but Few Limits

keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
